frameDefinitions: A generally large group of people, the Combatants, are engaged in a chaotic, violent, and usually protracted Fight amongst themselves.
An Assailant physically attacks a Victim (which is usually but not always sentient), causing or intending to cause the Victim physical damage.
A Protagonist comes to suffer from a Disease, often implicitly acquired from a Source.
A Winner has victory over an Loser.

A less-powerful person or group of people (the Activists) engages in an activity aimed to inconvenience or weaken a more powerful person or group (the Institution) to seek redress, in the form of a series of Demands, for the wrondgoings committed by the Instituion.  '

This frame consists of words that describe a hostile encounter between opposing forces (Side_1 and Side_2, collectively conceptualizable as Sides) over a disputed Issue and/or in order to reach a specific  Purpose. '' 'He still wants to fight Mike Tyson in about 8 months.'
frameExamples: As soon as he stepped out of the bar he was <t>set</t> upon by four men in ski-masks.
The workers were <t>striking</t> for better wages and better benefits.
He still wants to <t>fight</t> Mike Tyson in about 8 months.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Combatants</fen> participate as fighters in the <fen>Fight</fen>.
The violent activity.
When the <fen>Fight</fen> takes place.
Where the <fen>Fight</fen> takes place.
This role is the being or entity that is injured by the <fen>Assailant</fen>'s attack.
The person (or other self-directed entity) that is attempting physical harm to the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Assailant</fen> attacks the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Assailant</fen> makes an assault on the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The time at which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> contracts the <fen>Disease</fen>.

The location at which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> contracts the <fen>Disease</fen>.  It is different from the <fen>Source</fen> (usually marked with 'from') in that it does not necessarily mean that it was contact with the <fen>Place</fen> that actually led to infection.
The individual or individuals who beat the <fen>Loser</fen>.
The individual or individuals that get beat by the <fen>Winner</fen>.
When the <fen>Winner</fen> has victory over the <fen>Loser</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Winner</fen> has victory <fen>Loser</fen>.
The person or group of people that act out against the <fen>Institution</fen> in an attempt to have their <fen>Demands</fen> fullfilled.
The <fen>Institution</fen> is the company, factory, political party / institution, or entity that yields authority over the <fen>Activists</fen>.

The <fen>Demands</fen> are the guarantee(s) given by the <fen>Institution</fen> to the <fen>Activists</fen> that act to correct or address the issues or state of affairs that were grievous to the <fen>Activists</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location where the political action occurs.
One of two participants in a hostile encounter.
One of two participants in a hostile encounter, usually the second mentioned.
The jointly expressed sides in a hostile encounter.
An unresolved question over which the two sides of a hostile encounter are in disagreement.

The desired result of the outcome of the hostile encounter for the <fen>Side_1</fen> or for all the <fen>Sides</fen> collectively.  It may either directly refer to the state of affairs that is desired, e.g.
The <fex name='Time'>Time</fex> at which the hostile encounter occurs.
The location at which the hostile encounter takes place.
listRoleExamples: The football referee's controversial call led to a bloody free-for-all <fex>among the fans</fex>.
I couldn't help but watch as several bruised people reentered the <fex><t>melee</t></fex>.
The mysterious fighter attacked <fex>the guardsmen</fex> with a sabre.
<fex>The mysterious fighter</fex> attacked the guardsmen with a sabre.
<fex>As soon as he stepped out of the bar</fex> he was set upon by four men in ski-masks.
Then Jon-O's forces ambushed them <fex>on the left flank</fex> from a line of low hills.
While <fex>the U.S.'s</fex> battle with terrorist-harboring nations is far off ...
While the U.S.'s battle <fex>with terrorist-harboring nations</fex> is far off ...
<fex>They</fex> fought over the right to own land.
They had a dust-up <fex>over who was prettier</fex> .
He dueled with his former second <fex>to defend the honour of the man he had killed</fex> .
Following the battle of Naseby <fex>in 1645</fex> he died.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the John Howard Society of Saskatchewan
